Posts.Content: Oh dear, it does indeed show how important it is to be on the phone getting advice ... my chemo team now advise that patients call in if temp goes above 37.5 Hope you’re feeling more human again soon ... I have my daughter being sent home from college today as she’s been feeling sick, hope she’s not coming down with something! Take care xx
Posts.Title: My rush to A&E...

Posts.Content: It’s been good to read through this thread ... I had surgery 30th Nov 17, TNBC invasive 2.9cm tumour, removed with clear margins and no lymph involvement ... I started chemo (FEC-T) 16th Jan 18. Had 3 FEC, then 1 T but I’ve had so many problems after the first T that my oncologist has decided to both delay my 5th chemo by a week an put me back on FEC for cycles 5 & 6. I was originally down for Radiotherapy but then discovered almost at the end of Dec 17 that the BRCA1 gene fault is very strong in my dad’s family, so my oncologist told me I wouldn’t have Radiotherapy as I’d probably need risk reducing surgery once I’d been through all the screening etc and there wouldn’t be a need for Radiotherapy as a result. So I booked a long weekend break for my husband and I the celebrate our 30th anniversary on 8th June as it would fall after I’d finished my chemo ... but now as the gene people work so VERY VERY slowly, my oncologist says I’m going to have to have Radiotherapy because if we leave it until I’ve been through the counselling etc it will be too late for Radiotherapy ... I’m wanting to delay the Radiotherapy until after our weekend away. This thread has helped me see that the short delay I’m talking about here is not going to be a problem, although I’m still waiting to confirm the 2 planning appointments, I feel better about the request I intend to make. Thank you x
Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: Glad you like your new curls xx
Posts.Title: Embracing chemo curls

Posts.Content: Hi Catlover Take comfort from the fact you found it yourself, well done for checking yourself too xx I knew about my lump back in September last year, I didn’t do much about it then as I thought it was another cyst (I’d had a big one aspirated back in 2015). But then in October (saw GP 24th) I decided to ask to get the cyst Aspirated, so on 8th Nov I got my appointment with the Breast Clinic. Turned out that it wasn’t a cyst ... they did a Biopsy there and then. I had surgery on 30th Nov and I’m due to start chemo next week. Even though I left it those weeks, it hadn’t spread beyond the breast (mine’s the left breast too). You have done the right thing by going in right away ... hopefully it’ll be a benign lump that you’ve found. Try to stay positive hun xx
Posts.Title: Worried about breast lump I’m beside myself with worry

Posts.Content: Thanks Jaykay At present I’ll be going on FEC-T, a 6 cycle course. 3x FEC and 3x T. I’ll go take a look at the BRCA positive group and bring up the other stuff to the Breast Care nurse that calls me back.
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: An update: I saw the Oncologist today. I mentioned that the BRCA gene misprint was in my dad’s family and he asked that I find out who has had cancer and if they had been tested for BRCA or not. He said that Subject to being tested for BRCA, I wouldn’t be having Radiotherapy unti we know if I have the BRCA misprint or not. So I called my aunt ... and here’s the list! In my Nan’s generation: My Nan had her overies removed, but we don’t know why. Three great aunts also died from cancer, one we know which was breast cancer. In my Aunt’s generation: I have three aunts, one died from pancreatic cancer, not BRCA tested. Another is BRCA1 and had one breast removed. The aunt that I’ve been in touch with had ovarian cancer in 1997 and breast cancer in 2011, this is when she got tested for BRCA and this then started the whole thing off. She’s BRCA1 and has had a double mastectomy. In my generation: I have two female cousins who are both BRCA1 positive and have both had overies removed and double mastectomies (one age 34). In my daughter’s generation: So far there is one female who has been tested and she is BRCA1 and has had a mastectomy already. So I’ve left a message for the Breast Care Team to call me back. In the meantime, I will be starting Chemo either on 09/01 or 16/01.
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: Thanks Jaykay I’ve replied to the post you mentioned, I’ll certainly raise the issues when I get to speak to the nurse.
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: I am now 23 days post op (3cm, grade 3 TNBC removed by WLE, Plus clear SNB) and due to see the Oncologist on 27th Dec, to talk about starting my chemo treatment. I have just received a message from a concerned paternal aunt. The message was regarding the BRCA gene and that it is very strong in my dad’s side of the family. This aunt has herself had a double mastectomy as a result. I had heard of the BRCA gene but did not know it was of concern for me as my dad is not very good at feeding information (he seems to be in denial about my cancer, even though the tumour is gone now) to people who should know, I’m not in touch with the extended family at all, so I had no idea about this family trait. Now I am concerned about finding out more, my mum (dad’s useless) told me that my aunt (dad’s sister) does talks about the BRCA gene. I am now concerned about my daughter and also my grand daughter. I think we should all get tested, I am unsure whether to just ask the Oncologist about this or if I should call the breast Care nurse first thing on Wednesday (not sure if anyone will be there on 25th and 26th Dec). I’m thinking the oncologist will probably tell me to go see staff in the breast care unit anyway. My aunt did say for me to call her, but I’m not sure I’m ready for that yet, emotionally or otherwise, I’ve not seen her or spoken to her for many years (or any of the relatives on that side of my family really).
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: Granny59 ... we have a very similar saying down here in sleepy Devon: There’s nowt so queer as folk!
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: Thanks for the chuckle ... I don’t know if that was the intention, but at the end there, I will admit a chuckle!
Posts.Title: Something I’d like to share

Posts.Content: You don’t need to cope with the nausea, call your BCN or chemo ward and tell them, they can give you medication to help with that ... I ended up on a combination of 5 different ones. For the headache, make sure you are drinking at least 3 pints of fluids a day, I used to aim for 4. You can also take paracetamol but you do need to let the chemo nurses know as they can give you suggestions and get the right meds prescribed. They are there to help and wouldn’t want you to be suffering needlessly.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Well ... here I am, back inside! Neutrophils at 0.3!
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Peri menopause and hot flushes during chemo ... yep and yep! ... (I’m 50) My oncologist said to me at the outset that chemotherapy can cause, what he termed as, a chemical menopause. In younger women the periods can restart but in women who are peri menopausal they can stop and that’s that! Trouble is with the hot flushes! My periods were rather erratic before I started chemo and I had a period just a a week before I started chemo in January and I’ve not had one since. I found that my hot flushes were more viscous while I was taking the steroids in the week after treatment, then they calmed down a bit. I’m still getting plenty, day and night, now that I’ve finished my chemo, and as my cancer was Triple Negative, I don’t think I can go on HRT now, I was considering HRT price to finding out I had BC.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Well, well, well ... First of all, I’m allowed home today as my neutrophils have come back up to 0.7, somthey will continue building now... 5th stay in hospital complete once I have my meds and have been collected! Yay!! Second ... My Oncologist came to see me and told me that he’s cancelling my last chemo ... he said my marrow is knackered and as my chemo has been purely preventative it would be better to call it a day now and move on to the Radiotherapy. So that’s that ... not quite sure how to feel right now, I guess it’ll hit me when I get home!
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: May will see me have my last cycle of chemo (FEC-T that was to become 5 FEC with only 1 T). It had been a ride, that’s for sure! Treatment number 5 has seen me using 2 mouth washes every day, 4 times a day and I have not had so much of an issue with white tongue or cardboard mouth! i have, however, had more issues with my intestinal tract, it seems to have been more affected by the chemo this time, so I’m drinking Gaviscon daily now and that seems to be helping the Ranitidine keep on top of the acid etc. The saliva glands under my ears are grumping again. i am dreading the last treatment when it comes to how it’s going to effect my vein, it’s been very sore with the skin surface being sensitive to touch too ... it got pretty grumpy with the chemicals in cycle 5, made the nurses get a bit concerned as it kept stopping the flow of the drip for the last syringe! June will see mybhu and I celebrate our 30th wedding anniversary and then I’m also to begin Radiotherapy; for which I now have my three little tattoos! More joys, then recovery in July and maybe also find out about the BRCA1 issue.
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ah ha! It’s April, isn’t it? How did I miss that? New month, new club ... so I’m putting my last post from the March Club here, just for my own continuity (or something). I have two more treatments to go, next one is due next Tuesday (10th). All the tests they’ve done (stools, blood cultures, flu) have all come back negative. The discharge paperwork from Sunday had my diagnosis this time as being a Resolving Lower Respiratory Tract Infection ... which I didn’t even know I had! That was picked up last Monday when I went in and was released same day through A&E. I fully expect to be down there again at some point in the next 12 hours (whenever my temp decides to go up to 38 again; which it’s done pretty much every day this last week). I just don’t seem to have adjusted at all well to the T bit, maybe it’s the high dose my consul has me on? Plus I have a nice sore developing on my right wrist, currently roughly the size of a squished 5 pence piece, not sure what that’s all about! Hilary xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: This has been an issue since having the first T treatment on 20th March! It’s driving me crazy! I’ve been in and out of hospital and almost constant antibiotics for 3 weeks now, they keep saying it’s a resolving LRTI, the consultant tells me he thinks it’s viral because all the tests they’ve run have come back negative. My temperature has been up and down like a yo-yo. Every time it goes up to 38 again ... in I have to go for blood tests and more time in hospital, it’s driving me nuts!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I’ve had this problem Sammystaff, as well as it getting very sore due to loose stools. I have found aqueous cream to be very useful when wiping, a little dollop on some loo paper, which can then be flushed. Do that each visit and you’ll probably soon find relief d I’m still in hospital, they won’t let me out until I’ve had 24 hours with no temperature at all of 37.5 or more. It was 38.6 the other night, today my first temp taken was 37.7, my bloods show that I am very slightly anemic and the part of the white cells that shows you have an infection have gone up from 41 on Wed to 53 yesterday. So another blood test done today to see which way that’s going. Sadly my chemo which was due on 10th April is now going to be pushed back by a week!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Sammystaff I shaved mine off the day after most of it fell out, well I pulled it out in the shower when it started going as it was quite dramatic for me! I had my chemo on 16th Jan ... the events in the shower happened on 31st Jan but I found that what was left was painful, so the next day I shaved what was left and I’ve been shaving my head since then. I’m quite happy with no hair, apart from the fact that it’s cold! Now when I put on a wig, it feels weird! I have 2 scarves, 2 night caps and 5 wigs (3 fun ones and 2 normal looking ones). I do use cream on my head to keep it moisturised.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Me on holiday in Ireland August 2017, no idea of what was around the corner! After my shower on January 31st 2018 ... not much left! With my grand daughter on my latest release from hospital, while waiting to see the oncologist On Monday this week!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I am told I hide being ill pretty well, Cathy. I can feel atrocious but still look okay ... except when I had Sepsis last month; then I looked bad apparently! I have teased my husband with my staying bald , I am considering keeping my hair really short naturally allowing me to keep wearing my wigs ... time will tell. My grand daughter is my treasure, she is such a delight and always manages make me smile, I’ve missed our time together since my chemo and winter bugs just don’t mix ... I am so looking forward to having our time together back again. It’s been the thing that has caused me most grief in this whole process.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Well, I’m still inside ... but due for release tomorrow if the swap from IV to Oral antibiotics goes well! Keeping my chins up and can’t wait to get out of here!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: The nurse from last night went off shift, not sure when... sometimes they come and identify themselves when they start a shift but mostly they don’t seem to ... I have my meds, they were made ready yesterday - bonus! Now to try to find out what’s happening with the chemo!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: My temperature spikes have happened since my G-CFS injections. The said I did have a stay in hospital due to Sepsis after my last FEC, so when I had my first T treatment I had to have 7 days worth of G-CFS jabs. I’ve not been right since the T treatment, so my oncologist has put me back on FEC, as I can't have the Docetaxel without the G-CFS. So my Wed to Monday stay last week saw my chemo postponed by a week and the change back to FEC, then I had an overnight stay Fri/Sat just gone seems to have triggered another postponement, only no one saw fit to let me know ... which I’m cross about! I am now hoping that my body sorts itself out by next Tuesday so that I can get back on track again! I am at home and hoping to stay here until next Monday when I need to get mt pre chemo blood test! Keep strong everyone xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Well that’s me in for another nights stay ... on MAU for now, I may even make it up to the chemo ward; wonders will never cease! They’ve got me on IV antibiotics to try to chase away whatever the problem is, then more bloods tomorrow to see if one on the numbers stays the same or if it’s going back up again ... it’s to do with the white cells fighting off an infection. I’m a little bit aneamic too, not much but it’s there and what’s more, I’m not in isolation this time, yay for me!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Dear DL It was totally unexpected that I got changed back to FEC, part of the decision seems to have been the reaction I’ve had to the T and the G-CFS injections, I can’t have the T without the G-CFS injections as it’s too dangerous (having had Sepsis on the FEC). It may be worth asking your team about though, I hadn’t even considered it was a possibility.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ruby Rose  I am so sorry to see you have lost your mum so very suddenly. Hold on to all those positive memories you have with your mum. It’s good though to see you are feeling less negative about your chemo, keep talking to the nurses and your family, they can all help you. Take care of yourself xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thanks guys ... I did have to get grumpy last night though. I was told my cannula could come out at around 4pm, I asked three times about it coming out and was told someone would come and do it ... 4 hours and a shift change later, thevthing is still in my arm and the new nurse had said, I’ll get someone to do it. Shevthen came back 15 minutes later with my oral antibiotics! I was sat in my chair and she said shall I bring you some water? So I told her I wasn’t taking them until my cannula was removed, she went off muttering something, within 15 minutes someone came and took the cannula out! Never saw the nurse again ... maybe I’ll see her this morning with my meds? I am uncertain how many times a day I’m meant to have the oral antibiotics, I guess I’ll find out. I can self administer my Ranitidine and Cetirizine, so I’ll go ahead and do that as it’s now 7:14am. GET ME OUT OF THIS TEAPOT!!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I have my papers - Let the triumphal trumpets blare!! ... my son is going to come collect me, once he gets himself sorted out and then drives the 40 minutes or so journey. I also need to find out what’s happening with my chemo, has it been postponed or not?  My discharge papers say I’m still down for follow up this afternoon in Oncology, which I wouldn’t have know if I hadn’t have looked at them. Last thing I knew was they were saying it would be pushed back a week... no further information, so I’m going to have to enquire, which has to wait until after 9am! Onwards brave ladies, onwards!!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Well I’m home ... yay!! My oncologist has said he’s putting me back on FEC for my last two treatments as I have not had the best reaction to the T treatment or the G-CFS injections. 9 days (10 counting the one I spent in A&E) in hospital altogether. Plus as I have still not heard from genetics, he’s put me through for Radiotherapy to start about 3cweeks after I finish my chemotherapy. My next treatment will be sometime next week, from Tuesday onward. I’ve booked my blood test with my GP surgery on Monday, under the consultant’s advice! So now I want to enjoy my week ahead and will try not to over do anything! That I you all for you good wishes, I hope that I can get through the next two treatments without any further hospital stays!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: You are right about hiding illness and people not believing how you actually feel. I get it all the time! i don’t do it on purpose, except for just getting on with things ... my little brother said recently that the thing he’s always admired in me is my getonwithitness, I don’t know how to be any other way, even when I could scream from pure frustration. When I’ve had days (raising kids with autism) where I’ve just cried while stood at the window, took a deep breath and then carried on! Just get on with it, it’s how I know. It can actually be quite painful, when all you want is help and support but everyone else, just looks at the surface thinks you’re doing just fine! I am getting a lot of support now though and I am learning how to accept that suppor, although it does not come easy to me at all. Thanks to all for your positive comments, I hope everyone finds a good place from where to launch into their new and enforced profiles, it’s the new you for now and it’s only tempt, but it’s who you are now ... xxx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Aarrgghh!! Went for my chemo today, 45 minute journey each way! The lady at the desk said, oh I wasn’t expecting you until next week! It turns out that as I was in overnight on Friday my chemo has been pushed back another week ... only no one told me!! So I was told to sit in the waiting room and when the nurse came to get me, it was to ask about my temperature, which as it happens had gone back up to 37.6 at 1pm, so I’d taken 2 Paracetamol. Trouble is that it was still 37.6 at 3pm, so Dr said No, too dangerous! I now have to move all the other appointments that have been made and then hope that my temperature doesn’t go up high enough tonight to mean I have to go back in again ...  Just a tiny bit frustrated!!
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I started off with a little digital thermometer the goes under your tongue, we have since invested in an in ear one (not cheap) as it’s more efficient. i have also discovered that my ears regularly give different readings, so now I have to tell the nurses to check both ears as they have been almost 2 degrees different, only a handful of times have they been identical.
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Leolady56 No need to apologise at all, I have quite enjoyed telling the nurses they need to do both ears, somecare bewildered, some have come across it before. The one nurse came back and told me that shes discovered there was another patient on the ward that visit that also had odd ears! I hope you’re chemo goes well with as few SE as possible xx
Posts.Title: *** April 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***
